section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to review alphabet letters Pp, Tt, Vv, Zz; engage children with a song.
Introduce the vocabulary word (harvest).
Begin Story Time by introducing the book and asking, What fruits and vegetables do you like to eat?
Read for enjoyment and understanding.
Check understanding. Differentiate as needed.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Recognize different kinds of texts/genres; Use information to describe.
Produce at least 20 letter-sound correspondences.
Recognize and produce words that have the same beginning sound.
Talk and share.
Show understanding of what it means to be a consumer.
Sing, play musical instruments, and move to the rhythm in classroom activities.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Review the letters Pp, Tt, Vv, and Zz.
Help children recognize words that have the same beginning sound, focusing on Pp, Tt, Vv, and Zz.
Differentiate and modify as needed.

section-block.tg_essential-question: What foods do we like? Where do they come from?

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: What food is in the book? What does it look like?
What fruits and vegetables do you like to eat? Pretend you are eating your favorites!
Can you name three fruits? Can you name three vegetables?
Can you write about your favorite fruit? What words describe it?
What fruits and vegetables can you draw? What colors will you use?
What word makes the sound at the beginning of the word pumpkin? Can you write it?
What can you make to help you carry your fruits and vegetables?

section-block.tg_learning-goal-body: Mind Builders: Motivation and Creativity; Emotional Development

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to share the Mind Builder talk and share and introduce vocabulary (share, positive).
Begin Story Time by connecting the Mind Builder to From Our Hands .
Read closely and share and talk about the book.
Offer an extended play opportunity.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Use information to describe.
Produce at least 20 letter-sound correspondences.
Talk and Share.
Reframe the narrative in order to persist and self-motivate.
Show understanding of what it means to be a consumer.
Use language for different purposes and match language to social contexts.
Use art for self-expression.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Provide an opportunity for children to form the letters in their names in creative ways.
Encourage childen to talk and share ideas.
Differentiate and modify as needed.

section-block.tg_essential-question: What foods do we like? Where do they come from?

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: Can you find fruits or vegetables in your book?
Can you pretend to have a chat with Clifford about the book?
Can you make a picture of a basket of berries? How many berries are in the basket?
Imagine you are picking apples from a tree. Write about it.
What fruits and vegetables can you make with modeling clay?
What letter makes the sound at the beginning of the word tuna? Can you write it?
Can you build a farm?

section-block.tg_learning-goal-body: Literacy: Read-Aloud Comprehension; Phonological Awareness; Alphabet Knowledge; Writing

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to build background and teach vocabulary (feed).
Begin Story Time by revisiting From Our Hands and asking the guiding question: How do farmworkers help everyone?
Read interactively for deeper comprehension.
Check understanding and differentiate as needed.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Recognize and produce words that have the same beginning sounds.
Use information to describe.
Produce at least 20 letter-sound correspondences.
Contribute ideas and participate in group writing.
Talk and share.
Use language for different purposes and match language to social contexts.
Show understanding of what it means to be a consumer.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Help children recognize and produce words with the same sound.
Guide children to think of new words that begin with the same sound as other words.
Differentiate and modify as needed.

section-block.tg_essential-question: What foods do we like? Where do they come from?

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: How is the food in your book like the food you eat?
Can you pretend you are gathering fruits and vegetables? Show me how you gather them.
Why is it important for our bodies to have healthy food?
Can you write about where oranges grow and who picks them.
Can you use these materials to make your favorite fruit?
What word makes the sound at the beginning of the word vegetable? Can you write it?
Can you build a fruit market?

section-block.tg_copyright-line: TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved. From Our Hands with photographs by Ted Hoffman. Copyright © 2020 by Scholastic Inc. Published by Scholastic Inc.
TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved.

tg_materials-caption.tg_materials-caption_book-title-Ital: Big Chart of Big Ideas: Let’s Make Fruit Salad

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to talk about healthy foods and introduce vocabulary (fruit salad, ingredients).
Begin Story Time by connecting the texts Let’s Make Fruit Salad and From Our Hands .
Read closely to make a connection with the concept questions, How do farmworkers help you get the food you like to eat?
Offer an extended play opportunity.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Recognize different kinds of texts/genres; Use information to describe.
Write for different purposes.
Reframe the narrative in order to persist and self-motivate.
Show understanding of what it means to be a consumer.
Act out to recreate and retell stories, moods, or experiences.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Help children to pretend to make fruit salad using picture cards.
Invite them to use the picture cards to describe the process for making fruit salad.
Differentiate and modify as needed.

section-block.tg_essential-question: What foods do we like? Where do they come from?

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: How is the book like the one we read this week?
Pretend you are cooking. What are you making?
Can you tell me how we use cups to measure ingredients?
Can you write about how to make a fruit salad?
Can you use these materials to create a healthy fruit salad?
What word makes the sound at the beginning of the word zucchini? Can you write it?
Can you make a fruit salad?

section-block.tg_copyright-line: TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved. From Our Hands with photographs by Ted Hoffman. Copyright © 2020 by Scholastic Inc. Published by Scholastic Inc.
TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to sing about harvesting crops and introduce vocabulary (pick).
Begin Story Time by revisiting the book and asking, How do farmworkers help you get the food you like to eat?
Read and retell interactively for engagement and imagination.
Check understanding, differentiating as needed.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Use information to describe.
Write for different purposes.
Talk and share.
Use language for different purposes and match language to social contexts.
Show understanding of what it means to be a consumer.
Act out to recreate and retell stories, moods, or experiences.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Support children as they independently respond to this week’s prompt: Where does your favorite food come from?
Differentiate and modify as needed.
Save children’s writing to display next week.

section-block.tg_essential-question: What foods do we like? Where do they come from?

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: What was your favorite part of From Our Hands?
Pretend you are selling fruits and vegetables. What are you selling?
Draw a picture of an apple tree. How many pieces of fruit are on the tree?
Can you write a story about sharing a fruit with a friend?
Can you create a picture of all red fruits?
Can you find things in your station that start with the /p/ sound?
Can you build a vegetable farm?

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Use information learned from books by describing, relating, categorizing, or comparing and contrasting.
Produce at least 20 distinct letter-sound correspondences in the language of instruction.
Can produce a word that begins with the same sound as a given pair of words.
Talk and share.
Demonstrate understanding of what it means to be a consumer.
Participate in classroom music activities, including singing, playing musical instruments, and moving to rhythms.
Use information learned from books by describing, relating, categorizing, or comparing and contrasting.
Produce at least 20 distinct letter-sound correspondences in the language of instruction.
Talk and share.
Reframe the narrative in order to persist and self-motivate.
Demonstrate understanding of what it means to be a consumer.
Provide appropriate information for various situations.
Use art as a form of creative self-expression and representation.
Use information learned from books by describing, relating, categorizing, or comparing and contrasting.
Produce at least 20 distinct letter-sound correspondences in the language of instruction.
Discuss and contribute ideas for drafts composed in whole-/small-group writing activities.
Talk and share.
Demonstrate understanding of what it means to be a consumer.
Provide appropriate information for various situations.
Use information learned from books by describing, relating, categorizing, or comparing and contrasting.
Independently write to communicate ideas for a variety of purposes.
Reframe the narrative in order to persist and self-motivate.
Demonstrate understanding of what it means to be a consumer.
Create or recreate stories, moods, or experiences through dramatic representations.
Use information learned from books by describing, relating, categorizing, or comparing and contrasting.
Independently write to communicate ideas fora variety of purposes.
Talk and share.
Provide appropriate information for various situations.
Demonstrate understanding of what it means to be a consumer.
Create or recreate stories, moods, or experiences through dramatic representations.
